The statement "the medium is the message" was coined by Marshall McLuhan, a Canadian philosopher and media theorist, in the 1960s. The statement suggests that the medium used to convey a message is just as important, if not more so, than the content of the message itself. In other words, the way that a message is delivered and presented can have a profound impact on how it is received and understood.

This idea can be applied to the use of spots in art. The spots themselves can be seen as the medium, the visual language through which the artist communicates their message or intent. The way that the spots are arranged, colored, and shaped can convey different meanings or evoke different emotions in the viewer.

In this sense, the spots in art can be seen as both the medium and the message. The way that the spots are used, whether as focal points, areas of contrast, or elements of composition, can influence how the artwork is perceived and understood by the viewer. The spots themselves become an integral part of the artwork, conveying meaning and intent through their visual language.

Overall, the connection between the spot in art and the statement "the medium is the message" lies in the idea that the visual language of the artwork is just as important, if not more so, than the content or subject matter of the artwork itself. The use of spots in art can be seen as a powerful tool for communication and expression, conveying meaning and emotion through the arrangement and use of color and form.
